The  Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard  and the  Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society at Harvard University ¬† will host at least one fellow for an academic year to carry out a research project on #journalism #innovation. Candidates must propose a project relating to journalism‚Äôs digital transformation. Examples might include ideas for new revenue streams to fund journalism, the construction of new tools for reporting or research into news consumption patterns. POP QUIZ: What do you think is the best motivator for employees? a. cash b. free pizza c. praise and commendation Dan Ariely, Duke professor of psych. and behavioral economics, shared an experiment in which employees working at a semi-conductor factory were promised 1 of 3 things if they could assemble a certain number of chips per day: ‚Ä¢ A cash bonus of about $30 ‚Ä¢ A voucher for a free pizza ‚Ä¢ A complimentary text message of ‚ÄúWell done!‚Äù from the boss Interestingly, pizza was the top motivator on day 1‚Äîincreasing productivity by 6.7 percent over the control group. This is surprising considering the cash only motivated a 4.9 percent increase...and actually resulted in a 6.5 percent drop in productivity for the week. But even more interesting was what turned out to be the biggest motivator:  The compliment. Now, if the promise of a simple text message from the boss can increase productivity, can you imagine what real, sincere, and authentic praise would do? Read more about how to make YOUR praise authentic in my book: "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence." https://amzn.to/2sxFLho #EmotionalIntelligence   #leadership   #management   #PersonalDevelopment   #BestAdvice   #BusinessIntelligence   #careers   #culture   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

BREAKING NEWS! A woman staying at the Duesseldorf University Hospital died during a ransomware attack. It could be the first death directly linked to a cyberattack on a hospital. During the attack, the hospital couldn‚Äôt accept emergency patients and the woman was sent to a healthcare facility around 20 miles away. It's going to be extremely hard to catch these bad actors. What healthcare institutions can do is to prepare for such attacks by upgrading their cybersecurity systems.  I wonder how many hospitals worldwide employ cybersecurity experts. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #cybersecurity

This excellent article by  Chip Cutter  from his interview with New York architect  Vishaan  Chakrabarti casts light on the drab uniformity of today‚Äôs modern urban landscapes.  This is of particular relevance to Asia, where I live. So much of the beauty and distinctiveness of local architectural traditions, many dating back hundreds or thousands of years, have been literally bulldozed into oblivion, replaced by Western temples of consumerism.  Like the hutongs and courtyard homes of Beijing, or the grey brick shikumen style archways and homes of Shanghai, or the red brick structures of old Taipei. These are all almost entirely gone, replaced by the dull, utilitarian and frankly downright depressing structures we find ourselves in today.

Measuring heart rate by smartwatches and fitness trackers seem to not always work on darker skin or tattoos.  I knew of this issue and similar biases in A.I., also highlighted in The Medical Futurist e-book ‚ÄòA Guide to Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare‚Äô. I‚Äôm really glad Nicole Mpofu reached out to me and raised my attention to how they‚Äôre trying to tackle this issue  Codethink . Their team is working on designing a fully open-source research device for experimenting with shining light into skin and detecting the light that reflects, gets absorbed and passes through. The kind of technology that is widely deployed for measuring heart rates. Have you heard of any similar issues and solutions? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy

For so many of us, 2020 has been the year that won‚Äôt let up.üò´ In these crazy times,  #uncertainty  continues to plague us in business can be crippling‚Äîor empowering‚Äîif we allow it to be. Here are some reminders to help you navigate a ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù world: You can‚Äôt control what happens; you can only control how you respond.‚úÖ No one asked for the year that 2020 has been and continues to be. Rather than ponder why this is happening and lament circumstances affecting your  #career , remember there is one thing you can control: your response. Be mindful of what you consume.üß† ‚ÄúYou are what you eat‚Äù doesn‚Äôt only pertain to food; the same can be said in terms of the information you consume and its effects on your mental and physical wellbeing. Be aware of the people and sources you allow into your orbit, limit your exposure to those that trigger you, and seek additional perspectives that provide a balance of encouragement and  #positivity . #Perspective  is everything.üòÑ Asking and answering ‚ÄúWhat if?‚Äù tends to bring out extreme anxiety. But remember, you always have two choices: the worst-case scenario where you‚Äôre paralyzed by fear or the best-case scenario where you allow yourself to imagine the possibilities and become empowered by the potential of good. #leadership   #awareness

I have found that once you can figure out distraction in one area of your life, there is a ripple effect in all areas of your life.   It took me about 5 years to write my recently-released book, Indistractable. During those five years, my life has changed tremendously.   When it comes to my work, I love to write, but I kept putting off this work that I love because I constantly got distracted.   After writing this book and learning about distraction on a deeper level, I am writing more than ever. I have also experienced improvements in my health and in my relationships with my wife and daughter.   Watch below and share your thoughts! üëáüëáüëá   #Indistractable   #HumanBehavior   #Health   #Writing   #Distraction

I just read an article in InsideHigherEd about the 15 new incoming students at Hampshire College. IHE referenced a Boston Globe article describing the feelings of these students and those who chose to attend elsewhere.   Because Hampshire is struggling, they limited 1st yr enrollment.  And of those accepted, only 15 students deposited.  Reflecting on small entry classes, why is  it necessarily a bad idea to be one of those students and for some, it cld be beneficial. Start w/ this: the students know the institution is struggling. They chose to go to an institution that is free spirited and now working to solve fiscal issues.   Might that be like an adventure for some? A bonding experience?  Being a part of something bigger?  Pursuing new pathway in higher ed?  Isn‚Äôt that the Hampshire way?  Anti-complacency?  Yes, it might be a costly student experiment‚Äîfinancially and otherwise. But, this is not pro forma college with consistency; this is like an entrepreneur‚Äôs start up.  I raise this because I‚Äôm still struggling to save a small college that wld clearly need a soft reboot. I don‚Äôt think all students wld avoid that. Some might like the effort, energy, commitment. Just saying: small entry classes aren‚Äôt all bad. These 15 students are bold and brave.  Bravo/brava. Rainbows. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Until recently, the 406 students from Pelinia, a remote village in the Drochia district of northern  #Moldova , had no  #toilets  inside their school building. Like many buildings across the country, there was no sewerage system installed, which left them having to brave all sorts of weather to simply use the bathroom. The lack of running water also meant the simple outdoor facilities were often unhygienic. In 2017, 40-year old history teacher,  ludmila turcanu  ( https://lnkd.in/dyh5brg ) herself from Pelinia and a graduate from its local school, along with four other female teachers and a student decided to change this situation. Read about their empowered, inspiring efforts to improve the health and futures of their nation's children via  UN Women . #globalhealth   #globaldevelopment   Women in Global Health   #water   #sanitation   #hygiene   #WASH   #HealthForAll   #childhealth   #education   https://lnkd.in/dWWgyvX

According to National Geographic, ‚ÄúExtinction rates today are hundreds‚Äîperhaps thousands‚Äîof times higher. The last mass extinction, which did in the dinosaurs some 66 million years ago, followed an asteroid impact. Today the cause of extinction seems more diffuse. It‚Äôs logging and poaching and introduced pathogens and climate change and overfishing and ocean acidification. But trace all these back and you find yourself face-to-face with the same culprit. This time around, the asteroid is us." The photograph below shows the gap between what people in each country perceive as the percentage of protected land and water v/s what happens in reality. This made me think how we can be cocoon in our perceptions. How much do you think about climate change and personal choices? (Article link in comments)

The Medical Billing Advocates of America and CoPatient, claims 75 - 80% of medical bills have some sort of error, which are usually in the care provider's favor. That's why I'm so excited about this bill to push transparency and fair healthcare costs forward. Imagine waking up one morning and you can't see - which is what happened to me when I was running daily, practicing a very healthy lifestyle. In the blink of an eye, I was faced with six digits of medical debt. It could happen to you. Chronic illness doesn't discriminate. Strokes and heart attacks can cause permanent damage and insane medical bills. We can do better than this. Good health shouldn't depend on how much money you have in your wallet. #inclusion   #healthcare   #chronicillness   #invisibledisability   #publicspeaker   #chantelshares

#Socialmedia  notifications aren‚Äôt just robbing your time and  #attention ; they‚Äôre also increasing your stress and anxiety.üì≤   Here‚Äôs why you should turn them off:   You‚Äôll start your day less anxiousüßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Instead of starting your day with a sense of dread, you‚Äôll feel calm and peaceful, knowing that you‚Äôre not allowing external forces to dictate your mood.   It redirects your behavior to support conscious and intentional consumptionüéØ When you reclaim your time as your own, you decide when you want to check and engage on social media.   You‚Äôll have uninterrupted blocks of time to do deep work‚è∞ When you protect your time, you‚Äôll find it easier to have blocks of time to immerse yourself in deep work.   You‚Äôll be more productive and less busy‚úÖ When you‚Äôre not scrolling through and checking notifications, you‚Äôll have more time to do the things that matter most.   You‚Äôll be more present for others‚ù§Ô∏è When your notifications are off, your attention won‚Äôt be compromised, and you‚Äôll be more present for those that matter most.   It reminds you of what‚Äôs truly urgent and important‚ö†Ô∏è With notifications off, you‚Äôll realize that not everything requires an instant response, and not much is truly important and urgent.   #leadership   #career   #timemanagement   #productivity

The statistics don't lie:  just as with African American women, the  #maternalmortality  rates for black women in the UK are five times higher than for white women. This video powerfully explains the core issue: the lived experiences for these women, and how they are treated during interactions with doctors, nurses and even some  #midwives  in pregnancy and delivery settings. In 1980 I visited President Jimmy Carter in the White House. I was obsessed with politics. With the people who worked so hard to be ‚Äúgovernor‚Äù or ‚ÄúSenator‚Äù or ‚Äúpresident‚Äù. I think it was because I was insecure. I didn‚Äôt want to be just me. I wanted people to like me, to maybe even VOTE for me. At age 12. When my friends were starting to hold hands with girls and feel that first unusual stirrings of romance, I would go home every day and call Senators and Governors and Presidential candidates for hours. I've messed up. Because I haven't shown what it's really like owning a business. Here's "my" reality of being an entrepreneur. ‚úÖ I've had two failed businesses. In 2018 my power was turned off multiple times because I wasn't making enough money. Early 2019, I slept on my office floor for 2 months while we got our company off the ground. ‚úÖ My company has grown quickly. And it's been amazing. But 2019 was also a rough year. I skipped pay multiple times.  ‚úÖ I had to walk miles to meetings because I totaled my car and didn't have enough money for Lyft. ‚úÖ I rented out two of my apartment rooms at $500 a month each. It allowed me to live rent free a lot of 2018 while I focused on building my company. ‚úÖ I've been called a 'n***er'. Laughed at during the first pitch event I ever went to. Friends turn into enemies. Fellow creators turn on me.  Don't become an entrepreneur because of what it looks like. This is the worst thing I've ever done in my life.  But it's also the most rewarding thing I have ever done. And I can't imagine doing anything else. I'm a business owner because of the freedom. Because it fuels my curiosity. Because it allows me to empower others. Share this video with someone that needs to see this! üé•  #justQ  üññüèæüñ§  #entrepreneurship   #business

My TEDx was about standing out with a story. And there are few things that illustrate the power of story better than this.üëáüèΩ In the 60s a Harvard Psychologist, Robert Rosenthal, approached a school in California. Basically saying, ‚Äúhey, I have this test I can give your students to help you identify which students are special.‚Äù The kids were then separated into two groups ‚Äúaverage‚Äù and ‚Äúspecial‚Äù. A year went by and the test was incredibly accurate. The ‚Äúspecial‚Äù group blew the other group out of the water in everything from: test scores, curiosity, happiness, etc. Even the teachers were happier. The thing is, that test was 100% bullshit and the students were chosen at random.  So 1). A good story can help sell anything. And 2). Pay attention to the narratives that you‚Äôre telling yourself. Because stories have the power to create reality. #justQ  üññüèΩüñ§  #entrepreneurship   #PublicSpeaking

Americans spend $19B a year on gym memberships. Unfortunately, 44% of people quit just six months after joining. These numbers are disheartening, but not overly surprising. Humans are hardwired to chase short-term rewards over long-term benefits. I have struggled with working out for as long as I can remember, so I know that dichotomy all too well. As an obese child, my mother dragged me to the gym to no avail. As a lazy teenager, I desperately joined the wrestling team and never won a match. As an adult, I have tried to prioritize fitness many times, but have failed at each attempt. This was until I found Fitbod, a great app that has helped me consistently go to the gym for over two years. Beautifully designed and with over 3M downloads, it is among the highest grossing and highest rated apps on the Apple App Store. Fitbod has been more than useful to me, but I was surprised to learn that my book, Hooked, was useful to their founders. Fitbod is  Allen Chen 's brainchild and he told me that he designed the initial prototype based on the four parts of the Hooked Model. He identified the internal trigger as not knowing what to do at the gym. Check out the link ‚áí  http://bit.ly/2WsOuPM #Hooked   #InternalTrigger   #Indistractable   #Fitness   #Fitbod

The Farm Bureau  will be allowed to sell skimpy health care coverage while offering false hope of good quality health insurance to its members . I recommend watching this video all the way through. Google admitted to The Verge that it is disturbing, "It is designed to be." But there's something¬†undeniably "Brave New World" about it. Leaving aside the creepiness, the premise seems to be built upon the assumption that understanding the past and present is key to predicting the future. History tells us this is at best only partially true. Even if Google one day manages to harness billions of user data points to help coerce the desired behavior from both the individual and the wider population, I suspect chaos theory will kick in at some point: you¬†cannot predict the unpredictable. To quote Dr Ian Malcolm from Jurassic Park, "Life will find a way"¬†#futurism¬†#technologytrends

When it came to exposing their bad loans, Indian banks had been belly dancing but the Reserve Bank of India forced them to do a striptease. Want to read more on this? Read Tamal Bandyopadhyay's `From Lehman to Demonetization'. It describes graphically how some public-sector banks have been driving down the slow lane to death, loaded with bad assets. Many of the loans that had been restructured following the Lehman collapse continued to haunt them but they were in a denial mode till Raghuram Rajan drove the first of  its kind asset quality review, or AQR, for these banks.  The has traced the rise in the bad debts of Indian banks and tried to go to the roots‚Äîas to why assets go bad. Is it the inefficiency of the management? Is it the interference of the government? Rogue corporations? Or, is it about business cycles going bust? ¬†To read the book, visit:  http://amzn.to/2AucbeQ 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

You‚Äôre only one decision away from a totally different life. Making a positive, life-changing decision requires three steps for success: 1. Awareness When we‚Äôre unhappy, it can often feel like there‚Äôs no way out, but you always have options. The first step in making a  #choice  is the  #awareness  that you have one. At this stage, it‚Äôs not about editing yourself on what‚Äôs possible; it‚Äôs about being mindful that change starts with you and your attitude. (Note: choosing not to make a change is also a choice; if you‚Äôre not changing it, you‚Äôre choosing it.) 2. Attention with Intention Once you‚Äôve realized that change is an internal job, consider those things within your control and how they impact‚Äîfor better or worse‚Äîwhat you want. Bring your  #attention  to your  #intention , and ask yourself what‚Äôs the one thing you can do right now to bring you closer to your  #goals . This need not be a grandiose, sweeping gesture; the biggest change starts with a small step in a new direction. 3. Action This last step may seem obvious, but far too often, we fail to act even when we know that making a change is in our best interest. Nothing changes if nothing changes. And action begets more action, giving us the much-needed momentum to keep going, no matter how slowly we start. #leadership   #career

Firings forced me to look at my life situation, take a bigger picture than I was taking, and figure out the new slices of life I can now taste. Being rejected is an invitation to sample more from life. And having a checklist helped me ignore all the bad chemicals that were trying to bring me down. #Madoff forced me to look at my life with a bigger lens. I started new businesses. I channeled my frustration into more networking, into ideas, into experimenting with my creativity to try new careers. I do the items on this checklist almost every day. Thank you Bernie Madoff. You did very bad things. And I met you when I was lost in my life. This is not about you. Or about me. It's what you and I did together. Here they are... 10 things you need to do if you were #fired yesterday:¬† http://ow.ly/YhRN30iRjU6

I am so happy to see  #SupremeCourt  Justice  #RuthBaderGinsburg  at the top of this list of The Most Influential People in Global Policy for 2019. She's the reason I can spring out of bed at 5:15 am most mornings.  She helps me realize that I don't have the luxury to give up or give in. That no matter what your age or station in life is, as a woman you have a voice, and you have the right to use it. And you MUST use it. Her example teaches me that, God willing, I'll have another 20 or 30 years left to try to make a difference, to contribute something positive to this world if I work hard to stay healthy and strong. I'll be posting about some of the other amazing women on this list over the coming weeks, because these days,  #genderequality  is MY JAM!  Thanks to @Apolitical for compiling this list, drawn from over 9,000 nominations. ‚ÄúJust checking in.‚Äù ‚ö†Ô∏è WARNING! ‚ö†Ô∏è  Using ‚Äújust‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make you sound less aggressive; it weakens your message, dilutes its impact, and signals that you and your request aren‚Äôt very important. Here‚Äôs how to drop it: First, become more mindful of your wordsüß† Scan your  #emails , texts, and messages (and better yet, read them out loud). You might be shocked to learn how often that seemingly innocuous word pops up in  #communication .  Next, determine what you wantüéØ Identify if you‚Äôre looking for a status update or trying to stay on someone‚Äôs radar‚Äîas well as the urgency‚Äî so you can craft an appropriate message. Finally, substitute new, action-oriented phrasesüöÄ Instead of ‚Äújust checking in,‚Äù which screams ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt important or timely‚Äù to your intended audience, try an equally polite but far more direct approach: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to hear how the (EVENT/PROJECT) is going/went. Could you give me a quick status update by end-of-day?‚Äù Or ‚ÄúYikes! If your inbox is anything like mine, messages tend to get buried. I wanted to make sure things were still in progress. Let me know if you need any help.‚Äù By removing ‚Äújust‚Äù from your  #business   #writing , you‚Äôll add more power to your words and, more importantly, improve your chances of a speedy response. #leadership   #career   #IlluminateMe

How do you even begin to persuade someone who sees the world completely differently than you do? You must provide evidence they're likely to respect. Remember that people differ in background, upbringing, and culture; what one person finds convincing may not work for another. That‚Äôs why you must closely examine the arguments of your conversation partner. Ask yourself: ‚Ä¢	Who influences and inspires them?  ‚Ä¢	What research or sources do they cite?  Next, you can seek data and expert opinions from sources they are likely to heed. (Be careful not to misquote or take information out of context, which will erode your credibility.) These efforts are time-consuming and challenging. But it‚Äôs a well-spent investment, because it allows you to present evidence in a way that‚Äôs more appealing to your partner instead of wasting time on arguments they‚Äôre never likely to consider. Read more about how to achieve emotionally intelligent influence in Ch 6 of my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #BestAdvice   #leadership   #empathy   #PersonalDevelopment   #management   #negotiation   #relationships   #influence   #respect   #EQ   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

The Chinese consumer continues to power economic growth. Any potential increases in exports from the recently concluded trade deal with the US, however, will not.  This podcast also covers China‚Äôs emerging role as a leader in smart manufacturing, technology decoupling between China and the US, and how China could become an exporter of climate mitigation solutions. 3D bioprinting has recently seen some setbacks, especially due to Organovo's announcement about changing the company's course.  But this is something to provide hope again. A novel type of ink enables bioengineers to print bone-like material at room temperature with living cells. It's a big feat considering the fact that bone is a mixture of living and inorganic compounds in a highly structured mineral matrix. The team is trying to print larger samples and has begun small animal tests to see if a print can repair a large wound. In the US, the FDA has already signaled that 3D-printed bone technologies are eligible for FDA clearance. I‚Äôve explored what 3D bioprinting can do today and what it promises for tomorrow in various parts of my e-books on The Medical Futurist. Steve Jobs is best known for conducting one of the most stunning business turnarounds in history: leading Apple from the brink of bankruptcy to become the most valuable company in the world.  But many who worked with the famous founder had a love/hate relationship with their boss. Yes, he was inspiring and innovative. But he could also be overbearing, impatient, arrogant. In fact, it was those latter traits that led to Jobs infamously leaving Apple back in 1985, as Jobs and Apple's board simply couldn't see eye to eye. In the eyes of many, Jobs was a "brilliant jerk." So why is it, you may ask, that in a world that seems to increasingly value collaboration and soft skills like emotional intelligence, do brilliant jerks continue to succeed? The answer's not as simple as you think. (Read more in today's column.) #apple   #emotionalintelligence   #SteveJobs   #management   #leadership   #brilliantjerks   #eqapplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Have you ever wondered how generalists thrive in a specialized world? I recently had a chance to sit down with  David Epstein , author of Range, a fantastic book that covers this topic. Personally, I found the concepts of kind and wicked learning environments to be an interesting part of the book. David‚Äôs message: ‚ÄúIn wicked learning environments, breadth is the hack.‚Äù Watch the clip below and leave us a comment about how you‚Äôve found that having a breadth of experience or specialization has helped in your career or facilitated your learning! #Specialization   #CrossFunctionality   #Generalist   #Range   #Indistractable P.S. David‚Äôs book, Range, and my new book, Indistractable, were recently placed on the BookPal Longlist for the 2019 Outstanding Works of Literature (OWL) Award in the ‚ÄúBig Idea‚Äù category. The five books in each of the fifteen categories represent the top reading recommendations for individuals and teams to inspire new ideas, expand perspectives, and fall in love with reading. Congrats to all other authors and works on the Longlist! Check out the full release at the link in the comments below.

Dogs are people‚Äôs best friends‚Ä¶Especially Now.
 
 Studies show that they help us lower our blood pressure and deal with stress. But we don‚Äôt need studies to tell us what we know already! Dogs also help us get more exercise and spend more time in nature. They always love us and they are always happy to see us. In some ways, dogs show us what ‚Äògoodness‚Äô looks like in all of us too!
 
 Due to the ongoing pandemic, there has been an onslaught of negative news that can cause us to get mired in the spiral of depressing articles. However, it seems that a spike in dog adoptions during COVID-19 is one positive outcome that we can feel good about, as adoptions increased significantly in March and April. 
 
 So if you have a dog, or cat, or are thinking of adopting, make sure you have the  time--and love in your heart‚Äîto commit to them‚Ä¶Like they will commit to you.
 
 FTI Consulting‚Äôs Lindi Jarvis, CA, CFA, CPA CFF, and Vincent Flores, CFE contributed to this story.

Do you think about what you consume? I am not talking about food. I am talking about all your intellectual and digital consumption habits‚Ä¶the books you read, the shows you watch, the instagram accounts you follow. Here‚Äôs why -  Your output is only ever going to be as good as your input. I am downright snobbish about how I spend my time and what I consume. I don't mindlessly scroll through social media feeds. (I don‚Äôt even have Facebook downloaded on my phone - shhh). Your mental input will determine the quality of your life. And THAT is how you stay on track with your goals, aspirations, and hopes for life. What‚Äôs something you consume daily that you could trade for a better substitute? P.S. - Pre-COVID, I loved exploring new cities after my keynote. Great way to get fresh input. This was taken in London. If you want to process more on this subject, I was interviewed about what I‚Äôve learned as an entrepreneur and I shared my strategies for both personal and professional success. I‚Äôve learned a few things about  #content :   Just because you write something doesn‚Äôt make it valuable to someone else; it‚Äôs up to the reader to decide.   If you only use your content to sell, you‚Äôll turn people off. Instead, strive to be of service.   If you go on and on, meandering your way through a very long post with little punctuation, run-on sentences, and no clear point, you‚Äôll lose people.   If a reader takes the time to like, comment, and share your stuff, make sure to acknowledge their kindness.   And on that note, be sure to like, comment and share other people‚Äôs content that you think your network would find valuable. If it resonated with you, it probably will with others.   The best way to discover interesting and valuable content is to read ‚Äî a lot.   Follow people whose writing you admire, whether in your industry or not, and seek many sources of information, even if it makes you uncomfortable. You never know what you‚Äôll learn and from whom. Be open.   Content can inform, entertain, persuade, or inspire. Choose wisely.   Be yourself. Write the way you speak.   And be consistent ‚Äî in your creation, your voice, your sharing, your engagement.   Because my biggest takeaway is this:  Content may be king, but content comes from people. And people connect with people.

"What would you tell entrepreneurs that see your success and think you are too perfect to experience challenges?"üôÑ Oh jeez. I had a fantastic call with best selling author of "Why Me First" and Mindset/Performance Coach,  Kajal Khurana  from Singapore. I had to contain my laughter on-air because I've been dealing with rejection a bit more than usual. Three opportunities fell apart over the past two weeks. A rejection from a local publication for the second time. Personal health issues. And more... But at this moment when I was supposed to mentor others, I was able to recenter and digest my own advice. ‚¨á Lean into the rejection and understand that there is more out there for you. Your future holds greater things and losing these opportunities makes room for even BIGGER ones! Sometimes rejection is proof that you are going OUT there and doing MORE üëâ and that's a sign of effort on its own! Be proud of how far you've come, even if it isn't where you thought you should be. Agree? üëá #Rejection

In the formative stages of a startup, hiring the right talent is among the most important things a founder will have to do. And it‚Äôll be worth considering tapping into the skills and expertise of senior professionals while they are at it.¬† I am reminded of the book ‚ÄòOutliers‚Äô by Malcolm Gladwell where he notes that 10,000 hours is the magic number for greatness. That you need to have practiced and to have apprenticed for at least 10,000 hours before you get good at a task. In fact, senior professionals and retirees come having incubated their skills and talent for much longer than that. And, therefore, they are worth more for their experience than what their age accredits them with. Whether you engage them full-time or part-time, as a consultant or as a part of the in-house team, it‚Äôs certainly a good idea for young founders enroll the expertise of someone who‚Äôs navigated the deep waters of a formal organization and can guide them in their journey to building one. Perhaps I am so much in favor of this because I am aging myself! Nevertheless, with average lifespan expected to improve in the years to come - 120 years as per some estimates - we have to start thinking about longer-term productivity measures and workforce inclusion.

I don't know when ageist, misogynistic name bullying became a thing and acceptable, but it would be really awesome it that would stop. Someone's mother, daughter, sister, relative, friend is named Karen. Or Susan. Or Jenny. Or Sally. As someone who has personally been name bullied for years, I can tell you that it's not "cool" or "socially acceptable". It's ignorant, and hurtful. If you're using the Karen meme/reference (or Susan, or any other name), I kindly ask you to stop. If you see others doing that, please take the time to educate them that it's not OK to make people feel ashamed of their name, and kindly ask them to stop.  #kindness   #humanity   #dobetter

For a  #FlashbackFriday  during  #WorldBreastfeedingWeek2019 , I'm thinking back to the June 2018 graduation ceremony for  #midwives  at the  #EdnaAdanUniversity  in  #Hargeisa ,  #Somaliland . That's when I met some of the most enthusiastic, energetic and inspiring women I will EVER meet. Many had overcome incredible odds to have the privilege of being mentored by  Edna Adan Ismail . One of the young midwives I met, Kaltoun Yasin, sent me a  Facebook  instant message today to let me know that she is participating in  Harvard University 's  summer  #globalhealth  program, and that she led a presentation on  #maternalmortality  and  #morbidity  yesterday. Kaltoun took great pride in telling the audience that Madame Edna has surpassed her original goal of training 1,000 midwives in Somaliland, and that maternal deaths have dropped significantly since the training program began. At a time when I almost dread engaging with  #socialmedia  each day, I was so grateful that Kaltoun reached out to share her fantastic news. I'm determined to counteract the toxin and negativity in this world with good news like this just as often as I can. Midwife International   Harvard T.H. We are in the midst of the holiday season! As we approach the new year, I want to reflect on all that has happened in the past twelve months. I had a chance to travel the world, visiting beautiful countries like The United Kingdom, Australia, Thailand, and others! I released my second book, Indistractable, to an outpouring of support from all over the world. I had the opportunity to serve and impact many people through my work, resulting in recognition as a LinkedIn Top Voice in Tech for 2019 and nominations for other accolades. Above all else, I began to take back control of my attention, my time, and my life, leading to countless memories made with my family, friends, and loved ones. Through it all, I have emerged endlessly grateful for all that I am able to do and enjoy on a daily basis. I will continue to approach my work and my relationships with the same optimism that I have in the past. 2019 has been great! I have a feeling that 2020 will be even better. To you, my digital community, I say thank you for an incredible year. Happy Holidays and Happy New Year! I‚Äôll see you in 2020! üëã #Indistractable   #HappyHolidays   #Gratitude   #Reflection

More  Netflix  history. Prior to 2004/2005, the grey "security screen" printed on the inside of the DVD mailer that prevented people from being able to see what movie was being sent, was a tangle of grey squiggly lines.  After chatting with our Ops team, it was revealed that it didn't need to be that, it's just what was done. So, we changed it to genres instead.   Very few, if anyone, ever took the time to look inside at it. But it was an easy, low-cost way for us to express the Netflix brand. #netflix   #brand   #branding   #dvdmailer   #securityscreen

In addition to social workers, this will be a valuable course for school psychologists, educators, HR personnel, among others. The point is that many anniversaries are coming up and the prior traditions for dealing with anniversaries have changed. How do we handle the pandemic anniversary and the anniversaries of those who passed away from COVID? How do we deal with anniversaries of traumatic events like suicides and shootings and death by overdoses?  We need to plan and reflect ahead of time so we don't end up retriggering older trauma.  Hope to see you there. The time to do the planning is now.

Our sales team called themselves "data slingers."  10 years ago I was hired by  Mark J. Feldman  to grow a data services brand in a then-emerging  #B2B   #martech  space.  There were only ~100 tools on the map as  #demandgen  teams bought our prospect lists to fuel email/call blitzes.  Some did it well, others simply spammed the living daylights out of those CSV files. Today, not much has changed, and yet, everything is different. Over a decade later, even with 10x more tools, the task of acquiring contacts still threatens to derail even the best laid plans - but this time, it's  #ABM  at risk.  Why can't teams find the right contacts for accounts? Why don't more demand gen pros think in an account-based way, like Sales? Are we ever going to shake our MQL-based ethos? Mark is now the head of revenue operations at Localytics, and I've asked him back for a reunion with me live this Friday at 1:00pm ET for a conversation about how things have changed in 10 years, and today, how to solve this new (but old) ABM data problem.  Live here on LinkedIn we'll dig into: - The messy yet critical task of choosing target accounts, and why less is more - How to find, and use, contact records appropriately  - The truth about working with data slingers like us See you there? 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

I want to be honest with you. üëáüèΩ I quit my full time job when I was 22 to start my first company. I had no plan. And I guess long term that worked out for me.  But where I wish I could go back and reframe my thinking is this: I thought it was wrong to build something on the side.  I thought I would lose respect if I took a part-time job (even though I was struggling to keep the lights on). I looked down on people that didn‚Äôt jump all in. Which was SO naive of me.  I thought building a business was easy. Because the people I followed kind of made it look easy. One of the things I struggle with most as a creator & entrepreneur is showing the reality. I don‚Äôt show: ‚úÖ The boring stuff. ‚úÖ Us getting ripped apart by our business coach every week üòÖüò≠. ‚úÖ How much work actually goes into this. ‚úÖ The many mistakes we make.  ‚úÖ And I could go on and on. Thank you  Cory Savage  for prompting this thought. And thank you i.c stars for asking me to do the commencement speech this year.  2020 I want to spend more time talking about (and showing) the stuff that many of us tend to avoid. What do you wish you knew when you first started? #justQ  üññüèΩüñ§  #business   #entrepreneurship

On Saturday, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos posted a letter to Amazon employees on Instagram, detailing part of his company's strategy for the coming months in response to the novel coronavirus. One line that stuck out to me more than all the rest: "My own time and thinking is now wholly focused on COVID-19 and on how Amazon can best play its role." Take a moment to let that sink in: Time and again, Bezos has emphasized that Amazon's strategy is a long-term one, more concerned with continuing to evolve and diversify than with short-term goals and profit, something that investors have not always understood or appreciated.  But now, Bezos has made clear that he's entirely focused on adapting his business to a disease that no one even knew about a few months ago. So, what are the lessons for you & your business? The time for wishful thinking is over. The sooner you figure out a way to adapt to the effects of the coronavirus, the better the chance your business has to survive. (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #Amazon   #Microsoft   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #innovation   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

In a very short time period, the coronavirus has created massive shifts in our lives. One of the things that has changed is the way we manage distraction and how we stay productive during this time of extreme uncertainty.  Before the pandemic, I would‚Äôve advised most people to pay less attention to the news and less attention to social media -- but we‚Äôve reached a point where now these constant updates are necessary to help us navigate the world in a safe and responsible way.  I recently spoke to  Dave Boerger  about the best way to stay productive while staying informed as we navigate this crisis.  Tag a colleague who would find this video useful below!  #Indistractable   #Timeboxing   #Productivity   #News   #COVID19

Years ago I was in my first role as a manager, and I experienced an exchange I‚Äôll never forget.  I chastised a team member‚Äîwe‚Äôll call him David‚Äîfor a major blunder. My point was valid, but I surely could have delivered it better. David‚Äôs response was quick and cutting:  ‚ÄúYou know, you‚Äôre the kind of manager the rest of us hate.‚Äù Ouch. Of course, David could have been more tactful. But there was no use dwelling on that; there was value in this perspective.  So, I took a few moments to let my emotions settle, then came back to David. I asked him why he felt the way he did, and learned from his honesty. In the end, it made me a better manager‚Äîand it showed David that I wasn‚Äôt the jerk that he thought I was. That's the value of honest feedback, even if it hurts to hear: It will help you grow... If you let it. Check out more in chapter 2 of my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #EQ   #leadership   #management   #BestAdvice   #careers   #BusinessIntelligence   #communication   #relationships   #PersonalDevelopment   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

In Other News: A Win For Patients Personal Digital Charts as I call them, or soon to be known as ‚Äòpersonal digital medical records‚Äô are coming to your smart phone soon! Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. ‚ÄúPatients should have control of their records, period. Now that‚Äôs becoming a reality,‚Äù said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. ‚ÄúThese rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.‚Äù Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions ‚Äîa good first step for all of us. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

What is keeping you sane? What's keeping me sane, while I wait for a deus ex machina to flip the switch that will return everything to normal, is my trusty rusty exercise bike, purchased years ago for $200 from a neighbourhood gym that was upgrading its equipment.  After ten days of riding in place, I'm chafed and sore, like I've been ravaged by an army of plundering Pelotons, but the sweat that puddles on the floor of my laundry room is my elixir. I'm in charge of manufacturing my own opiates now. I can no longer outsource my joy.  #healthandwellness

On the surface, the Cybertruck launch was a disaster. Even many Tesla fans admitted they thought the new E-Truck was ugly. And after Musk boasted that the truck's windows were practically unbreakable, Tesla lead designer Franz von Holzhausen, um...broke them.  But fast forward a bit. Within a week, Cybertruck had won over many of its fiercest detractors. Over 250,000 people were so enamored they were willing to deposit a hundred dollars to be among its first potential owners. So, how do Musk and co. do it? How do they manage to build products that customers are dying to get their hands on? Musk revealed the answer to that question in a recent interview: "A lot of times I think people try to make products that they think others would love but they don't love them themselves. If you don't love the product, you should not expect that others will." (Read more in today's column.) #Tesla   #ElonMusk   #Cybertruck   #innovate   #disrupt   #leadership   #management   #BusinessAdvice   #EmotionalIntelligence   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

What and how you share your wisdom matters. Ask yourself if you‚Äôre committing these common  #thoughtleadership  sins: 1. You only share the wins Nothing is a bigger turnoff than someone who is continuously boasting. People respond to those who are genuine and admit when they‚Äôve made a mistake. 2. You push your product or service Don‚Äôt make the mistake of using your platform for blatant self-promotion. Instead, provide value by serving, not selling.  3. You try to cover too much ground Stick to those few areas where you are expert. When you stay within your wheelhouse, your audience sees you as the go-to person. 4. You never get to the point Meandering signals that you‚Äôre unorganized and unsure. Keep to one brief, compelling message. 5. You share haphazardly or infrequently Regularly and consistently publish your wisdom, so your network looks forward to‚Äîand trusts‚Äîyour insights and observations. 6. You post & ghost Merely posting isn‚Äôt enough; you want to start conversations and build relationships, so engage with those who engage with your posts. 7. You‚Äôre not telling a consistent career story People want to learn more about thought leaders. Create a cohesive, up-to-date and engaging presence that aligns with your content and supports your positioning. #personalbranding

See this new article on Princeton and women in leadership. I think it re-hashes what we know (mentoring matters) and misses culture change and self reflection.  My comment follows link:  https://lnkd.in/dTZf4wG I am struck by the total focus on mentoring for women; this is important to be sure and it is not new. What is striking is that there is almost no mention of institutional culture and the need to change that. How important is it to create an environment in which women can thrive as leaders. Were I to institute a look-see at Princeton, I would look at culture first -- what is it in the culture that enables men to seek and thrive in leadership posts. Hard to look inward and admit that there may be cultural biases and impacts and auras. Hard to face a male dominated past and current culture. Hard to be honest about what is inhibiting success. Mentoring matters for real. But, it is not enough. No indeed.

Recently, I shared a report that stated: "It takes roughly seven patients presenting after an abnormal pulse alert to establish one clinically actionable cardiovascular diagnosis." I described that you cannot expect one digital health technology to solve a medical issue in itself. And you cannot avoid using such technologies in healthcare to provide sufficient care. This is why digital health is a cultural transformation where you can't just drop a technology into the system and expect everything to get better. You need both patients and medical professionals to be on the same page, discuss the expectations and side effects and work together by using that technology. This is the topic that we address in the newest article on  The Medical Futurist .  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

Today we are publishing an interim edition of Sarah Jeong's 'The Internet of Garbage' available for free download on  theverge.com . Sarah recently left The Verge to join The New York Times and was almost immediately subjected to an astonishing vitriolic attack by right wing trolls. I found it genuinely horrifying to read the death threats (and far worse) directed at a colleague I knew to be anything but the racist she was inaccurately being portrayed as. Sarah, of course, dealt with it grace and humor telling me that at least the trolls were using a decent photo of her. The irony of course is that in her book (first published in 2015) is a seminal work outlining just how online harassment works. You should read it.  https://lnkd.in/dnbMHrq

This is how my activities looked like last year as tracked by my smartwatch. Apart from motivating me to move regularly and consciously, it has also helped me sleep better and wake up at the right time with the smart sleep alarm. Keeping track of these, I pay more attention to walk around every single hour because I want to have 7-9 active hours out of the 9 it tracks. On the other hand, I'm glad it doesn't emphasize the hours I've spent sitting in front of a computer or in traffic jams. I can‚Äôt stop thinking about the women and girls I met last week at the Fistula Hospital in Borama, #Somaliland. Their stories of pain and isolation were absolutely harrowing, but their strength and determination to survive, and someday thrive, still inspire me.  #Fistula is not just an abstract medical term. For tens of millions of women worldwide, the physical damage endured during childbirth can lead to a life sentence of suffering. And now that I‚Äôve seen the face of it, I‚Äôll do all I can to raise awareness. United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA)  #fistulasurgery #maternalhealth

The absence of a concession by Trump is but one of the difficult issues our students need to process and understand.  I just published a free download for educators on how to discuss the election in a non-partisan way. Once the concession issues are unfolded and addressed, I will add more to the list of teaching tools. I have also recognized that in a world of online learning, some of my books need to be made available as PDFs. That now includes the Tongue Twister book and the Lady Lucy Laugh Giraffe book, both of which are trauma responsive. They can be found at  https://lnkd.in/eaWQeJ6 .  In terms of resources, there is also a Trauma Toolbox How To Guide and The Feeling Alphabet Activity Set, also available at a reasonable price on my website. Finally, I am working on a Holiday Kit -- a type of trauma responsive bag that will help children and families navigate the inevitable changes of the coming holiday season (no Santa's lap; no in person caroling in close proximity.  Please access these resources.  Our children need them -- the amount of trauma is real and not declining.

Despite the upbeat news on the vaccines, I think we are struggling mightily across the nation with three key issues: (1) Pandemic fatigue including Zoom fatigue; (2) Absence of interpersonal touch and connectivity; and (3) Upcoming holidays and "tradition" changes that distance us.  In a sense, the second "surge" feels, at least to some of us, worse than the first surge; the numbers are perilously high; we have a dysfunctional transition of power (whatever your political persuasion) that is harming our nation. Some of us have become more isolated than perhaps even necessary due to fear as others flaunt mandates and best practices.   In a sense, we are unaccustomed and unprepared for what is happening in our nation.  We can rightly ask: how do we move forward with grace and wisdom and perspective?  What compensatory mechanisms can we deploy to help all those who need help? And, what about our children and their ability to navigate forward?   I have one thought: I have hope.  I still believe despite some evidence to the contrary that people are decent and caring and at the end of the day, the better side of humanity and the wiser voices will rise to the top and be seen and heard.  I still have hope.   Do you? 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

GOOD OR BAD: MONOGAMY  Having strong opinions are like a disease. You get one, then your friends get the same one (else, according to the rules of groupthink they are no longer friends) and so on.  I hate opinions. There always seems to be someone smarter than me who has the opposite opinion.  But I'm skeptical. And I like to know things. And think. And learn. And study. AND be entertained. And laugh.  I'm launching a new podcast soon with my friend and bestselling author, AJ Jacobs called "GOOD or BAD". We take topics: Dogs, Monogamy, Cars, Government, Billionaires, Tipping, Democracy, Cosmetic surgery, etc and argue:  "Is this good or bad?"  Sometimes we have a conclusion. Sometimes not.  Here is a teaser for one of the episodes: GOOD or BAD: Monogamy.  If you have suggestions for "good or bad" topics, please let me know in the comments.  Or, if you have opinions on monogamy, leave them in comments and I hope we read out some comments in the episode.  Enjoy! #podcast   #monogamy   #dating   #polyamory   #podcast   #opinions

Someone should coin "the law of 2020".  It means if you post something positive these days, people try hard to find the negative.  If you dare try and laugh, people will scald you. If you share good news, people will point to privilege or bad news to counteract it. Any wonderful data point is met with " yeah but what about XXXX"  If you point out the huge signs of progress in the world, people will point out your ignorance. It's driven by the media, and their accidental ( and unacknowledged addiction to cheap clicks, which play to misery and fears)  Its distorted our sense of the world, it's genuinely blinded the media to any positivity and algorithms neutralize the ability of good or reassuring news to spread.  It's like a giant self righteous woke festival of misery, a competition to be more anxious, more pious.  There is zero evidence life should be lived in a serious manner. We are all going to die. We can fight for change and justice and for better, and maybe without being so god dam miserable and judgmental and serious. It's not some giant competition to self flagellate with self imposed misery, unless I missed the "this is life in 2020" email.

Work has radically changed. It's time to embrace it. When you equip and empower your employees to adapt and find the tools they need to be effective and efficient it is an investment in your company‚Äôs present and future profitability.  Recently I worked with the largest independent Coca-Cola distributor in the United States. Their remote sales team worked hard, nights and weekends and rarely took time off.  However, sales call volume and sales numbers were down. Morale had plummeted. Paperwork, emails, phone calls, and unmet goals were piling up. Management realized that their team members were frantically busy, but not terrifically productive.  We worked with the sales team members, managers, and the sales leadership team and boosted productivity and performance. As a result, the remote sales team's  total sales calls per week went up over 20% from the prior year, which translated into $2 million in additional revenue.  Embrace the new world of work and make an investment in your company‚Äôs long-term growth and profitability.

What can you do when doctor shortages do not allow a country to provide care for everyone? You send out junior doctors to rural regions without any major experience. This is where artificial or augmented intelligence can jump in.  A Chinese company, RXThinking, is training medical algorithms to become super-diagnostician that can be dispatched to all corners of China. Instead of replacing physicians with algorithms, RXThinking's A.I.-based diagnosis app empowers them because it acts like a navigation app for the diagnostic process, drawing on all available knowledge to recommend the best route but still letting the physicians control the decision-making process. Just one example how and why A.I. is crucial for solving healthcare's global issues. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

Waiting on pins and needles, going crazy figuring out how to dress for the interview or how to wear your hair... Intimidated by body language and unexpected questions during the in-person interrogation, that makes your stomach flip... When I applied for a job as a Marketing Manager for an IT academy I was invited for an interview, One of the six people interviewing me started to pick on me for using the word "dazzled" in my cover letter. It was totally on brand,  But this engineer didn't dig that flavor or my bubbly nature, regardless of skill. Right then I knew it wasn't a fit. Needless to say, I went from having dreams of working for a small IT academy to writing for Thrive Global, working for millionaires across the globe on how to amplify their personal brand and thought influence. A lot has changed over the years. And I still use the word "dazzled" wherever possible üòâ Never dull your flavors to fit into someone else's recipe, especially when seeking a fit in your career. If you're looking for ways to build a culture that attracts and retains top talent, read my love story... #Culture   #Inclusion   #Success 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Some folks think  Netflix  launched streaming fully formed. The reality is that when streaming launched, nothing about it could be considered "great." The streaming quality wasn‚Äôt there and the library of titles available to watch was sub-par. Which is why it was launched as a free add-on for subscribers. Also, at-launch, you could only watch via a PC. Then, eventually a Mac. But the challenge the company faced was how to tap into the TV. Smart TVs and internet-connected DVD players were not widespread. Enter gaming consoles. Why? Because the goal was to get Netflix on as many internet-connected devices as quickly as possible. And game consoles already had installed user bases in the tens of millions and their consoles were all connected to the internet. So Netflix partnered with  Microsoft  XBOX,  Sony  PS3, and, believe it or not,  Nintendo  Wii. This was a mock-up of the sticker used on XBOX360 LIVE Gold physical packaging from 2008. Note the title count (12,000) and the rarely defined free trial duration. It‚Äôs Finally Here: Machines As Doctor and  Diagnostician  Researchers found that deep learning algorithms correctly detected disease in 87% of cases, compared to 86% for healthcare professionals. Wow. Many of us who follow ‚Äòdeep learning‚Äô and AI markets have seen this in radiological images (X-rays), and now there is evidence that machine-based data accumulation can ‚Äòcrunch‚Äô and analyze information to provide better diagnoses than a doctor who has seen hundreds (or thousands) of patients with a similar disease or problem.  Think of what this can do to bring more reliable diagnoses to patients and, think about how such technologies can help patients in under-resourced areas get diagnosed and treated sooner. Talk about Democratizing health care! This is a huge leap forward for Public Health. Now....how do we get Humans to trust Machines?? Selected Excerpt: ‚Äú"Machines... can have a massive impact on problems in healthcare, big and small, but unless we can convince clinicians and the public of its safety and ability then it won't be much use to anybody..‚Äù

Drawing on scientific research and personal experience, authors and friends Lynne Everatt, Deb Mangolt, and Julie Smethurst created Acts of Friendship: a comprehensive, fun and hilarious how-to on overcoming disconnection in our increasingly isolating world. Divided into 47 activities to strengthen friendships old and new, Acts of Friendship is designed to give friends the time and space to reconnect with each other‚Äîas well as with their environment, their emotions and their values. Make a ‚Äúchuck-it‚Äù list of things you‚Äôll never do; go on and hike in order to let go of old grudges; communicate your gratitude through haiku. Embark on collective action to reduce your carbon footprint; luxuriate in chocolate facials to rebuke conventional beauty standards; discover your inner child by puzzling over an ‚Äúages eight and up‚Äù toykit; or host a ‚ÄúDinner of Truth‚Äù and lovingly confront your most annoying traits. In an era of individualism and isolation, Acts of Friendship is a powerful guide to unity and empathy, reminding us that only through deepening our bonds with both the people and the world around us can we arrive at lasting fulfillment  #actsoffriendship   #workplacewellbeing  .

Ten years ago, when a McKinsey consultant left the firm, chances were they headed toward a bank, private equity group, or another professional service firm‚Äîin London, New York, Berlin, or another big city. But as our firm changed more in the past decade than at any other time in its entire 96-year history, so did our alumni network. We‚Äôve integrated analytics, AI, digital, design, and other capabilities into the new ways we work with our clients. We‚Äôve opened new offices in 41 cities, many of which lie in emerging markets across Africa, Eastern Europe, and Southeast Asia. And we‚Äôve grown; McKinsey today is 30,000 colleagues strong. So today, that same consultant leaving our firm might launch a mobile healthcare service in India. Or develop self-driving cars in California. Or ‚Äì heading even farther afield, to the stratosphere ‚Äì lead a startup to clean up space debris.   #mckinsey   #careers   #professionalservices

Join Chantel Soumis and Jason Lebowitz as they continue their focus this week on Anxiety.  Anxiety is a normal and often healthy emotion. However, when a person regularly feels disproportionate levels of anxiety, it might become a medical disorder. Anxiety disorders form a category of mental health diagnoses that lead to excessive nervousness, fear, apprehension, and worry. Last week we began the conversation by talking about general anxiety.  Today's focus will be on Social Anxiety.  Social Anxiety is a chronic mental health condition in which social interactions cause irrational anxiety. For people with social anxiety disorder, everyday social interactions cause irrational anxiety, fear, self-consciousness, and embarrassment. Symptoms may include excess fear of situations in which one may be judged, worry about embarrassment or humiliation, or concern about offending someone. Come join in the discussion and leave your comments and questions.  The show streams live at 10 AM CST.

Here are five reasons why saying yes is one of the best decisions you can make for your career: 1. It opens you up to new challenges and opportunities. If you wait until you feel ready to pursue an opportunity, chances are it‚Äôll pass you by. Saying yes means that you‚Äôre open to moving past your comfort zone and embracing a new challenge.  2. It invites collaboration. There‚Äôs a reason improvisation is rooted in the phrase, ‚ÄúYes, and...‚Äù Unlike no, which shuts down conversations and progress, saying yes opens up positive possibilities and invites others to build together, fostering collaboration, partnership, and further discussion. 3. It empowers and affirms others. As a leader, choosing to say yes acts as an affirmation to others and their ideas: I hear what you just said. You‚Äôre paying attention, and they matter. And giving the green light signals trust, which empowers others. 4. It creates an environment where it‚Äôs safe to try, fail, learn, and innovate. When you freely say yes, you create a risk-tolerant environment. You encourage innovation by trying new things and using the successes and failures as learning opportunities. 5. It makes life more fun. Saying yes can bring you new sources of joy and lead you on an incredible adventure. #leadership   #career   #growth 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Empathy in founders is a highly underrated skill. And yet the best founders I have interviewed are deeply empathetic, often because they have had to overcome their own adversity. One such founder is the brilliant founder  David Rogier  of  MasterClass  who I had the pleasure of interviewing earlier this year. He said in his interview:  ‚ÄúI stutter. When I was a kid, it was bad. I was teased in school about it. My family refused to let me use it as an excuse. One day I decided to tell my grandfather that I stuttered and was being teased in school for it. He gave me a hug and said ‚Äî ‚ÄúSo? You going to let that stop you?‚Äù In his eyes, if you weren‚Äôt in Auschwitz‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre OK. My parents would not let me use my stutter as an excuse to temper my curiosity (to not ask questions). They always expected my brother and I, from a very early age, to participate in dinner conversations with their friends. They were incredibly loving and determined for my brother and I to achieve whatever we wanted.‚Äù  https://lnkd.in/em3TwNg   #founders   #startup   #entrepreneur   #entrepreneurship   #innovation   #tech

When I was 7 my parents and teachers didn't think I'd ever be able to read or do basic math, because of my debilitating dyslexia. I was lucky enough to work with an amazing educator who convinced me that my dyslexia was a superpower. My confidence grew, and I realized that the problem wasn't that I couldn't learn - it was that the standardized resources and tools being thrown at me were useless.  Once I was able to understand my dyslexia, I was able to master it and use it to my advantage. The same is true for ANY weakness. Get to know yourself. Get to know your faults. Then grab them by the horns, and use them to unleash your full potential.  Interviewer:  Bryan Elliott 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

I‚Äôm very pleased to share our new China Luxury Report 2019: How young Chinese consumers are reshaping global luxury My colleagues at McKinsey surveyed more than 1,000 young Chinese luxury consumers on what makes them tick, unlocking insights into their perceptions of luxury as a form of social capital that distinguishes them from peers in the world‚Äôs most populous nation. Our report suggests that by 2025, spending on luxury consumption in China will increase to 1.2 trillion RMB, in the process capturing 65% of additional global growth, and accounting for 40 percent of total global spending. For luxury brands selling high-end shoes, bags, fashion, jewelry, and watches, winning in China means nothing less than winning the global luxury race. https://lnkd.in/fXEJpa8 #mckinsey   #china   #luxury   #consumers   #socialcapital

Being in a new role as the Head of Product in a company that has so many exiting opportunities going on for it and that the roles of the product, design, and development are so key for its success, could be a lot to take on. When I reflect back on how I gained my skills and learned some of the best practices I'm utilizing in my new role, I felt I owe a huge "THANK YOU" to a few of the product and design leaders I've worked with in the past and learned tremendously from. Thank you  Tim Roberts ,  Marianne Braunstein ,  Sumner Paine ,  Nick Myers ,  Jonathan O. , and  Ayse Kulahci . I'm putting a lot of the things I've learned from you into practice every day. DeepMind  just made a nice gesture and shared its predictions about the protein structures of the coronavirus, which causes the COVID-19 epidemic.  The system uses a machine-learning technique known as "free modelling" to help it predict protein structures when no similar structures of protein are available. They decided not to wait for a peer-reviewed paper but published the results now.  They emphasised that "these structure predictions have not been experimentally verified, but hope they may contribute to the scientific community's interrogation of how the virus functions". A.I. in action. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #covid19   #coronavirus

It was great catching up with McKinsey's global managing director Dominic Barton in Hong Kong today.¬† I had the pleasure of working with Dominic back in his Shanghai days, when he led our Asia practice. In the nine years that he has led our firm, we've expanded into many innovative areas of client service, from data analytics, digital transformation, and design, to new business-building, implementation, and leadership development. We've also vastly expanded our reach into new locations around the world. Dominic has spearheaded the founding of Generation, an innovative program that places disconnected young adults in jobs, giving them the skills and support they need to achieve enduring personal and professional success. Since its creation in 2014, Generation has launched in 47 cities across 5 countries ‚Äì India, Kenya, Mexico, Spain, and the United States.¬† In total, more than 10,000 students have graduated and 84% of them have found jobs. You can find out more about the program here:¬† https://lnkd.in/fSbZQUE

I have been doing a lot of thinking lately about how the government spends money -- how it allocates its dollars (our dollars).  I have been struck by the no-bid Cerner contract with the VA to move to electronic health records which is estimated to cost $16 billion.  No typo.  See:  https://lnkd.in/e-bR3RW .   So, here's my question: What can you get for $16 billion if we had other spending priorities?  What disease could we cure for that amount?  Could we have universal early childhood education for that amount?  We have legislation with mandates that are unfunded; suppose we looked at some of those to fund?  A recent NY Times piece noted the proliferation of child pornography on the web and the absence of sufficient resources allocated to stomping out this problem. The legislation exists; the dollars don't. Bottom line: How can a private company get a $16 billion no bid contract when we have so many other needs?   Ask yourself: What can $16 billion buy?

The question about A.I. is never technology vs humans. GM Garry Kasparov introduced the concept of advanced chess, also known as cyborg or centaur chess. He wanted to bring together human and computer skills to achieve the following results: - increasing the level of play to heights never before seen in chess; - producing blunder-free games with the qualities and the beauty of both perfect tactical play and highly meaningful strategic plans; - offering the public an overview of the mental processes of strong human chess players and powerful chess computers, and the combination of their forces. The most exciting medical studies that used machine or deep learning did not conclude that algorithms are better than physicians at doing a specific task but those that showed how the combination of computational and human cognition leads to the best results.  My favorite studies in this are the ones with detecting breast cancer on slides and diabetic retinopathy on retinal images. Excellent results underscoring the notion that artificial narrow intelligence will work with medical professionals and vice versa for the best results.  Have you seen other similar studies concluding the same? Photo source:  Kasparov.com #digitalhealth   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Gary Vaynerchuk  says it's one of the biggest things to which he attributes his success.  Simon Sinek  believes it's the most important instrument in a leader's toolbox. And  Oprah Winfrey  cites it as fundamental to leadership. The secret of their success is something that might surprise you: EMPATHY. This soft skill is often misunderstood and confused with its cousin, sympathy, which is feeling compassion for somebody.   But empathy is about putting yourself in someone else‚Äôs shoes and seeing things from their perspective.   How can YOU be more a more empathetic leader?   First, shift your mindset to put people first. See them as human beings rather than a means to the end of a transaction or task.   Next, ask thoughtful and probing questions that draw out implications and feelings.   Finally, use your awareness to give others your full attention and truly listen to what matters most to them.   When you do these things, you‚Äôll better understand your customers, colleagues, and partners, and then be able to use those insights in ways to better serve and communicate with them.   And in this way, empathy can give you an edge as a leader‚Äîand as a human being.   #empathy   #leadership   #business   #success   #relationships   #communication   #growth   #softskills   #career   #HumansFirst   #growthmindset

The surge in emerging market bond issuance illustrates how Federal Reserve policies have opened wide the debt markets to those not having direct support. Per the data complied by Gramercy (thank you), the $327 billion in issuance YTD compares to $278 bn last year and $292 bn in 2018. The good news is that this massive bond issuance has allowed developing countries to avoid liquidity problems/other short-term problems turn into solvency/longer-term problems. Less good is the encouragement to cuspy (in terms of liquidity/solvency) borrowers to over-rely on debt financing. #markets   #debt   #em   #emergingmarkets   #fed   #centralbanks   #federalreserve   #gramercy  @gramercy

Here is what is worrying me (among other things): recommendation letters. There is a history of such letters being written for teachers to get new positions despite the fact that these teachers have abused students.  We often are less than honest (if omission counts) when we write letters of recommendation.  We assume receivers of letters can read between the lines and know that we are not truly recommending someone but we are being cautious to avoid charges of defamation, libel and other legal risks.   So, posit this hypothetical: write a recommendation letter for Bill O'Reilly.  What should it say? Would all references to sexual abuse/harassment be absent from such a letter?  Ponder this conundrum; recommendation letters are commonplace. 
 
 
 ‚Ä¶see more

Stories need conflict. So ask yourself, what's the conflict in your life? Over the past few years I've gotten so comfortable at opening up and sharing my past. But I'm not so great at sharing what's going on currently (because I'm always so focused on getting through it). But that's something I'm working on as I move forward.  Because conflict is a gateway to connection. It makes your story relatable. That doesn't mean that everything you share has to be about hardship. Or that you need a rags to riches story.  But trickling in the adversity that your facing (or have faced) is a great way to take your content & story to the next level. Just something to think about. #justQ  üññüèΩüñ§

The ongoing coronavirus epidemic differs from the SARS, MERS and the Ebola outbreaks of recent years from several aspects. On the one hand, the virus spreads much faster than other viruses of recent times (though its death rate is fortunately lower). From driverless taxis to automated cargo trucks, autonomous vehicles (AVs) will change the nature of on-road driving and, in the process, revolutionize the automotive and mobility industries. Within this mix of opportunity and uncertainty, we believe AV players (from components vendors to mobility service providers) could earn trillions in revenues in China. In the long term, China will likely emerge as the world‚Äôs largest market for autonomous vehicles. In fact, the Chinese automotive market is already adopting ‚Äúmobility-as-a-service‚Äù (MaaS) at a rapid rate. For example, cars sold to provide mobility services today represent about 10 percent of China‚Äôs total cars sales, and the country‚Äôs mobility-services market has grown at double-digit rates over the past several years. When  Netflix  launched streaming, it was only available on PCs. Then on Macs. Then game consoles (XBOX 360, PS3, Wii). Then came the opportunity to be available via  Apple TV. However, despite a back and forth between  Reed Hastings  and Steve Jobs, Jobs stuck to guns - no color logos on AppleTV.  It was too big of an opportunity to let get hung up by the desire to always use a full-color logo so I had the task of trying to figure out how to best represent it with those constraints.  These were the ideas I came up with. If I remember correctly, we ended up negotiating with Apple to either the 2nd or 4th one on the right. But in looking at this again, if you take away the box on the 3rd one on the left, it bears an odd resemblance to the logo as it is today. #Apple   #AppleTV   #Netflix   #logo   #design   #SteveJobs   #NetflixHistory   #netflixlogo   #brand

I just got back from San Diego, where the American Economic Association held its annual conference. I've been going to the meetings for close to a decade now, and this year's version looked and felt different. Job interviews (the conference doubles as a giant hiring fair) moved out of hotel rooms, where female candidates have long felt uncomfortable. There was an ombudsperson holding office hours to hear about harassment and abuse. There were even lines for the ladies room. In other words: Economics has made progress in the year since its longstanding problems with sexism and racism burst into public view. Many people told me they have seen the beginnings of a culture shift. And there have also been more concrete reforms: new committees, new policies, new enforcement mechanisms. But it is still unclear whether those reforms will translate into deeper, more lasting change. And in terms of hard numbers, economics has a long way to go: Gender and racial gaps in economics are wider -- and have been more stubborn -- than in many other fields. For more, see my story with  Jim Tankersley  and  Jeanna Smialek  in today's  The New York Times . #economics   #diversity   #gender   #race

Help me understand.¬† ¬†We have shootings in workplaces and that doesn't stop the way we treat violence and guns. We have shootings in an elementary school. Same outcome. We have shootings at a concert venue. Same outcome. We have shootings in churches (most recently in Texas). Same outcome. ¬†We have shootings on campuses. ¬†Same outcome. ¬† Safe places -- work, worship, schools -- are now unsafe. Why aren't we doing anything about guns and gun violence? ¬†Last time I checked, these guns were used to kill innocent people, not animals in the wild and not for self-protection. ¬†Without some change, we will not see change in the violence is protected places. What kind of world is that? Oh, we blame mental illness. ¬†Perhaps there has been mental diminution in those who have been the shooters. But, isn't there a link between access to weapons (their purchase and continued use) and gun violence? Might it be time to reconsider--finally --quality background checks, limits on numbers of purchases and a national database that works. What will it take? Post being shot, even Rep. Scalise was not against guns.

Have you ever been stuck in a rut? Have you felt like you can't get out of it, no matter how hard you try? When you are diagnosed with an incurable disease like cancer, it's easy to grieve and get stuck in a mental rut. Even as the "bubbly and blessed" I have felt my fair share of darkness fighting illness! We get out. We fight through the pain. We rise up and make the best of a very dark situation! Because the clouds WILL part üå© and the sun will come back out üåû Weathering the storm isn't about the cards you have in your hand... but about how you play the cards you've been dealt. That's why I stepped up to this challenge... AND I HAVE LEARNED A LOT! ‚úÖ I have been rejected over and over again... ‚úÖ Folks I NEVER thought would make a contribution showed up with extreme generosity... ‚úÖ While those I thought would give ignored my inquiry. And THAT'S OKAY. This is a big challenge, but I'm here to fight for the loved ones I've lost and know that as a parent, NO mother or father should EVER have to lose their baby to cancer. Let's cure it. This is my WHY for the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society  Please consider making a monetary or auction donation here:  https://lnkd.in/gdjKxAB #MWOY   #GiveBackChallenge   #Healthcare   #Gratitude

I‚Äôve been called ‚Äútoo‚Äù competitive. I like to win. I like to learn. And culturally that‚Äôs been a bad thing. But I‚Äôm learning that if I‚Äôm going to ‚Äúwin‚Äù I need to lean more into the person that I am and make my strengths (and weaknesses) work for me. And for me it‚Äôs simple: am I outworking the old me? Am I better than the old me? Am I working towards the me that I want to be? At the end of the day there is no one on the planet with the same goals + plans as you. No point in competing with someone that‚Äôs playing a different game with different rules. Your only [long term] competition is you.  #justQ  üññüèΩüñ§

Just imagine me under the üéÑ , giving my grandma her present: an inflatable belt. I‚Äôve got a hard time picturing this, but who knows?  I‚Äôve given serious thoughts to this after I interviewed  TangoBelt ‚Äôs Product Development Engineer,  Megan Riley . Falls among the elderly can ruin or even claim lives everywhere in the world. Hip fracture is the most common result of such a fall and it can take months of recovery ‚Äì if one ever recovers from it.  According to Johns Hopkins Medicine, one in three women and one in five men will have a fracture at some point after age 50. Check out the interview and learn what Tango Belt can do for your beloved seniors!  https://lnkd.in/ebkcHmM   üí° Please note: Patreon members of The Medical Futurist get early access to interviews such as this, and other premium, handpicked content. Your media presence extends beyond what you do in print, video and social media. It's how you present to customers, staff, clients. Think holistically and strategically about the image you want to portray. Once your brand is established, be consistent in every way. It's good to surprise your audience now and again, to entertain a bit, to employ strategic content marketing tactics to engage them, for instance. But above all, people appreciate knowing what to expect - substance, style, all of the above.
